discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
That's a tricky one!
The question implies that the shared project is located on the personal drive of the user who's on long-term leave. In that case, B is the correct answer.
In case the data was stored in a Shared Drive, even if the user was owner of that data, their suspension would not interrupt the access of the rest of employees, therefore answer A would suffice.

Selected Answer: B
I think it's B.

questions.question_text: An employee at your organization is going on long-term leave for an unknown period of time. Their teammate is working on a shared project and needs access to all the project files owned by the employee on leave. You must grant access to all these files efficiently. What should you do?

choices.A: Suspend the Workspace account of the employee who is on leave.
choices.D: Locate, download, and share the project files with the teammate.
choices.C: Locate the folder that contains the project files by using the security investigation tool. Make a copy of the files for the teammate.
choices.B: Grant the teammate access to the project files by using the transfer ownership functionality.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
logical is b

choices.D: Search for the Meet log events during the time of the Meeting by using the security investigation tool.
choices.A: Check to see if there was a Google Meet outage at the time of the meeting by using the Google Workspace Status Dashboard.
choices.C: Check to see if Context-Aware access rules were set to prevent Meet access from the user’s network location.
choices.B: Check the user’s participant statistics by using the Meet quality tool and entering the corresponding meeting code.

questions.question_text: An employee at your organization had very poor quality during a Google Meet video call from their laptop. They were at a coffee shop and not on the corporate network during the meeting. You must troubleshoot the issue quickly and efficiently. What should you do first?

choices.A: Single tenant, because it simplifies administration and centralizes policy control.
choices.B: Single tenant, because each business will have a super administrator account to separate responsibilities.
choices.C: Multitenant, because each business prefers to manage itself.
choices.D: Multitenant, because it simplifies user creation and collaboration across domains.

questions.question_text: Your organization has migrated to Google Workspace and has several different tenants from different businesses they have acquired. The IT team is considering whether to consolidate all of their tenants under a single Google Workspace tenant or allow certain domains to have an additional tenant for separation. What approach should you suggest and why?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A multi-tenant solution is a complex, cost ineffective solution.
B is wrong because in terms of security, as there should be only one super administrator account. Any IT employee who needs specific access to Workspace's services can be given specific admin roles for that, according to Least Privilege.
Even if there are different policies for each business, that could be easily arrange with different Organizational Units per Business and the application of different policies per OU.

choices.D: Create a content compliance rule that warns the user when they’re sending any outbound email that contains sensitive data but still allows sending with proper justification.
choices.A: Create a content compliance rule that blocks any outbound email that contains sensitive data.
choices.C: Create a new Activity rule that sends a High severity alert for any outbound email that contains sensitive data.
choices.B: Create a Drive Data Loss Prevention (DLP) rule that blocks content with sensitive data.

questions.question_text: Your company maintains a strict privacy policy regarding the external sharing of certain information. You need to scan and block any outgoing email that contains certain sensitive data, such as credit card and national ID numbers. What should you do?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A because we want to block

questions.question_text: Your organizational policies require that all documents containing personally identifiable information (PII) are labeled as “Sensitive”. You want to scan all files in your corporate Drive and apply the label to all files containing PII. What should you do?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct.

Selected Answer: A
C and D are not correct because it refers to the application of Sensitive Labels to all Drive files, without checking their contents.
B is not correct because after the labeling of existing Drive files, it requires users' action for newly added files, therefore it is not an effective and autonomous solution.

choices.A: Create a data protection rule for Drive that automatically applies the label named “Sensitive" to Drive files with PII.
choices.B: Create a data protection rule for Drive that automatically applies a label named “Sensitive” to new Drive files with PII. and requires users to add a label to previously created files with PII.
choices.C: Enable data classification for your corporate Drive. Create a label named “Sensitive" that is automatically applied to all new and previously created files in your domain.
choices.D: Enable data classification for your corporate Drive. Create a label named "Sensitive” that is automatically applied to all new files in your domain.
